questions.question: Match the scale of measurement.

pairs.right: Equal intervals, no true zero (e.g., Temp)

questions.explanation: Nominal=categories, Ordinal=ranks, Interval=equal distance no zero, Ratio=true zero.
questions.hint: Think about the level of measurement precision.

questions.question: Which measure of central tendency is the only one appropriate for Nominal data?
questions.explanation: Mode is the only appropriate measure for nominal data.
questions.hint: Think about which measure works with categories.

questions.question: A distribution where the tail points to the right (high scores are few) is ___BLANK___ skewed.
questions.explanation: Positive skew has tail to the right (few high scores).
questions.hint: Think about the direction of the tail.

questions.question: Which of the following are measures of variability (dispersion)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Range, Standard Deviation, and Variance measure variability. Mean measures central tendency.
questions.hint: Think about measures that show spread.

questions.question: In a normal distribution, the Mean, Median, and Mode are all equal.
questions.explanation: In a normal distribution, Mean = Median = Mode.

questions.question: Which graph is best for continuous variables where bars touch each other?
questions.explanation: Histograms are used for continuous data with touching bars.
questions.hint: Think about graphs for continuous data.

questions.question: What statistical test is used to determine the relationship between two categorical variables?
questions.explanation: Chi-square test analyzes relationships between categorical variables.
questions.hint: Think about tests for categorical data.

questions.question: A Type I Error occurs when:

options.text: You reject a true Null Hypothesis
You accept a false Null Hypothesis
You reject a false Null Hypothesis
You accept a true Null Hypothesis

questions.explanation: Type I error is rejecting a true null hypothesis (false positive).

questions.question: Order the steps of qualitative analysis.
questions.explanation: Steps: Organize → Create categories → Analyze/Interpret → Write report.

questions.question: Descriptive statistics are used to make inferences about a population from a sample.
questions.explanation: Inferential statistics do that; Descriptive statistics summarize data.
